posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hi everyone

Happy holidays to everyone at the ECB

I've been exploring tanky rogue builds, I like my rogues strength based, clad in full plate + tower, plenty of HP and skill points and of course as much sneak attack as possible.

This is an idea I came up with. 32 Base Str, 470+ HP, 425 skill points, Base AB 41 with 20d6 sneak attack, improved knockdown, crippling strike, evasion/improved evasion, slippery mind, +6 to saves against spells. this guy looks like a bit of a beast.

Uncanny Dodge II onwards provides some pseudosneak sneak attack resistance, although if I took 5 levels in dwarven defender that would have provided sneak attack immunity when flanked but not flatfooted (which would be a different build, I wouldn't be able to dump the dex stat and lose a lot of skill points or HP).

One could go human for an extra 43 skill points to get to close to 500 skill points and a pre-epic bonus feat which you don't really need, or halfling for bonuses to saves but I liked dwarf for this build for the +2 to saves against spells, extra HP and other combat related bonuses.

Weakness is the will save which I've mitigated with Iron Will / Slippery mind feats and 21 crossclassed points into spellcraft for +6 to saves against spells so hopefully the will score of 18 won't be too much of an issue.

If you wanted you could drop the sneak attack a little by taking an epic skill focus feat in discipline to make you very difficult to knockdown or disarm, but there seems something special about the 20d6 sneak attack value, its like a zebra amongst a bunch of horses.

Dev crit can be included by dropping iron will, resist energy: acid and expertise and two great strengths for power attack, cleave, great cleave, overwhelming critical and devastating critical. Will drop your Base Str to 30 and Base AB to 40. It is very nasty looking for a rogue. 

Anyway haven't play tested this one but I think this looks like a good one.

I haven't had a proper look yet, Orion, but a first thought is that you could boost your saves by +1 by taking Fighter 4/ CoT 4. The downside would be the loss of some Concentration, but you'll know which is preferable for your environment.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Thanks Stag for having a look, I originally designed the build with R32/F4/CoT4 but chose to max concentration in this build to make it taunt resistant, in WoG every enemy seems to taunt you, I think its one of the package AI things from the NWN vault they have used, is it called Tony's AI or something?

With the R32/F4/CoT4 level split concentration can be maxed, but I would have to take F4 late, which would mean delaying WS/EWS too late, so I adjusted the levels to R32/F6/CoT2 to allow conc. to be maxed and WS/EWS to be taken midway throughout the build

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
Looks good, personally I refrain from small COT (below 8 levels) as I find you are better off with small Paladin dips instead. Unless you are Feat starved (you are not) or Charisma anaemic (you are, but by choice).

I’d lean towards human with 2 Paladin levels over 2 COT levels, drop int to 14 and raise Charisma to 12. Net the free human feat to balance the loss of the COT feat, the human skill bonus to balance the skill point loss for dropping int to 14.

You end up 40 HP lower but immune fear, immune disease, have an equivalent +1 to all saves immediately but offers a more flexible all saves bonus depending on your world for equipment/buffs of course netting up to +6 more over COT AND Paladin saves bonus does not count towards the saves cap which more than balances out the dwarf spell saves with room to spare. As an added bonus, freeing up your belt slot for +4/5 Charisma gear :)

If you are on an RP server, keep COT, the mechanical advantages of a small Paladin dip over a small COT dip are not worth the RP agony of playing a Paladin IMO.

... not worth the RP agony of playing a Paladin IMO.
The more stereotypical you make your character, the more limited becomes the roleplay. And that can soon become a problem in multiplayer even if you have an in depth understanding of your character and try to play it according to that, simply because people keep telling you what paladins can do and not. Even DMs may fall into that trap, and that can make life hard for a serious roleplayer.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
If high SA is a focus, BG may be the best warrior class for the build. But the saves will suffer as long as the cha is so low. Epic rogue bonus feats from rogue 16 and onwards let you pick ISA.
If the build has one leftover level, you can squeeze in a single assassin level for one more d6.

posts.author: Menhir Rocksolid
posts.content: A lot of sneak attack dice are only really useful if you are able to knock down your foes. I would generally prioritise AB over an overabundance of SA dice. Furthermore, more than 3 rogue levels are typically only really useful when going for epic dodge (which is however DEX based). Dex is simply more amenable to high level rogue builds. 16/20/4 Rogue/Cleric/Fighter will likely serve you better if you want be a Tank (with epic dodge and tons of buffs) and quite a bit of SA.

Hi Menhir
Thanks for commenting! Happy new year!

I did think about making a dex version of this build, in addition to epic dodge the melee and ranged AB, AC, reflex score and dex based skills will be better plus one can consider dual wielding and stealth. It is  attractive. I'm just used to making Str based characters really, I haven't quite learnt the art of playing a dex-er yet.

That being said I thought an AB of 40-41 was pretty decent for a build with 30+ rogue levels

There are lots of ways to get sneak attack without knocking enemies down, solo this could be as simple as hitting them around a corner, using invisibility pots, or UMD to cast a summon and flank them. In a party there will be a multitude of ways to get sneak attack, from simply flanking them in combat, to your mages, druids and cleric casting powerful disable spells such as Bigby's, SoV or Stonehold.

By the way on the topic of higher AB, if you want even more AB, you might be interested in this draft build  I made. Dev crit scimitar, Base AB 45, 450+ hp, 13d6 sneak attack, max taunt, WS/EWS at lvl 21, its pretty nasty. The main weakness is the will save which UMD is handy to manage. I've played it in WoG to level 38, I probably should put it in the lvl 40 section somewhere, but haven't gotten around to it yet.

posts.author: Menhir Rocksolid
posts.content:
Hi Orion,

Thanks for the welcome.

I have in the past (a long time ago) primarily been making builds fro PvP (Bastions of War) so I generally build PvP. The thing is however; whatever works against human opponents generally still wrecks anything PvE (maybe more slowly, but they will go down, and the toon wont). Naturally, server rules or which specific module you're playing (which items are available) will hugely affect what is optimal. I mean, some server nerf the cleric quite a bit and whether knockdown immunity or haste items are available for example also affects a lot. Generally, (ignoring XP penalties or RP) I find the Paladin class a lot more powerful than the Blackguard class. This largely boils down to 1: Divine Favor, Bless, Aid, (Extented) Prayer and GMW (depending on items on server). Again, if reaching the +20 to attack cap is easily attainable on the server/module these arguments diminish (this is even more important in regards to Clerics).

Again for Dex, Paladin mixes better with BG as you don't need to pick Power Attack and Cleave. From a pure vanilla perspective, Blackguard mainly only mixes well with Bard and RDD (26/4/10 Bard/Blackguard/RDD).

Hey Menhir

Thanks for telling me about your PvP experience
I have no PvP experience and primarily build for PvM, the environments I mostly play in are World of Greyhawk PW, Aielund, the Bioware campaigns, I logged into Blackstone Keep briefly as well. I guess such environments might be fun for some but I just don't enjoy hurting other players, I'd rather the DMs create a challenging and changing environment to deal with, preferably in a party

We are diverging off topic here hehe we should move a few of these posts into a new paladin vs blackguard thread

RE Paladin vs Blackguard in PvM, I wouldn't say paladin is 'a lot more powerful', I used to think so, I think there are certain advantages to taking Blackguard that are under-utilised, which include avoiding xp penalties, role-playing matters, sneak attack, full BAB class pre-epic, epic bonus feats every 3 levels from level 10 onwards which include all the good ones like EWF/EP/Dev Crit/AS, two summons/day including the Vrock to help sneak attack enemies, avoiding significant investment in wisdom, stackable bull's strength, use poison if its buffed.

Honestly in pre-epic levels Blackguard is a lot of fun, and the Vrock is still useful later on

And seriously role playing is much more fun as a blackguard. 'I'm a big bad blackguard and I'm going to kill you with my undead and demonic summons and big bastard sword' is much more interesting that the good old paladin's 'a good deed is its own reward' -> that is way too selfless heh, particularly after a long day at work when you've been giving of yourself to others for most of it

You can avoid taking power attack and cleave by taking one or more levels of monk for a dex build, its probably quite desirable anyway for the crazy APR particularly with dual kamas, to add a little sneak attack
